Authors: Zhu J., Hirai Y., Sakai S.-i., Zheng M.
Title: Potential source and emission analysis of polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxins and polychlorinated dibenzofurans in China
Affiliations: Research Center for Eco-Environmental Sciences, Chinese Academy of Sciences, P.O. Box 2871, Beijing, 100085, China; Environment Preservation Center, Kyoto University, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto, 606-8501, Japan; Research Center for Material Cycles and Waste Management, National Institute for Environmental Studies, 16-2 Onogawa, Tsukuba-Shi, Ibaraki, 305-8506, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Zhu, J., Research Center for Eco-Environmental Sciences, Chinese Academy of Sciences, P.O. Box 2871, Beijing, 100085, China; Hirai, Y., Environment Preservation Center, Kyoto University, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto, 606-8501, Japan; Sakai, S.-i., Environment Preservation Center, Kyoto University, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto, 606-8501, Japan, Research Center for Material Cycles and Waste Management, National Institute for Environmental Studies, 16-2 Onogawa, Tsukuba-Shi, Ibaraki, 305-8506, Japan; Zheng, M., Research Center for Eco-Environmental Sciences, Chinese Academy of Sciences, P.O. Box 2871, Beijing, 100085, China
Abstract: The Chinese Government ratified the Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs) on 25 June 2004. As a party to the Convention, China is preparing its National Implementation Plan (NIP), which must be finished and submitted to the Conference of the Parties before November 11, 2006. The emission inventory and strategy for reducing unintentionally formed products is a very complex and difficult part of the NIP. In this paper, we analyzed the potential sources of polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxins and polychlorinated dibenzofurans in China and calculated their possible emissions. We included municipal solid waste incineration, hazardous and medical waste incineration, pulp bleaching, sodium pentachlorophenate production and usage, illegal electrical and electronic waste ("e-waste") recycling, and ferrous and non-ferrous metal production, and prepared a preliminary analysis of dioxin emissions in China. The results show that ferrous metal production (104.2-6648.3 g TEQ), non-ferrous metal production (2.6-3389.8 g TEQ), and sodium pentachlorophenate production and usage (120-368.0 g TEQ) should be major potential sources of dioxins and furans. Moreover, municipal solid waste and hazardous and medical waste incineration (35.5 g TEQ) should also be considered high priority sources owing to a rapidly increasing incineration ratio anticipated for the near future. © 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Congener pattern; e-Waste; Emission inventory; National implementation plan; POPs; Sodium pentachlorophenate
Index Keywords: Chinese Government; Congener pattern; Dioxin emissions; E wastes; e-Waste; Electronic waste; Emission inventories; Emission inventory; Medical waste incineration; Metal production; Municipal Solid Waste; Municipal solid waste incineration; National implementation plan; Non-ferrous metals; Persistent organic pollutants; Polychlorinated di-benzo-p-dioxins; Polychlorinated dibenzofurans; POPs; Potential sources; Preliminary analysis; Sodium pentachlorophenate; Air pollution; Chlorine compounds; Herbicides; Incineration; Industrial wastes; Metallurgy; Metals; Organic pollutants; Refuse incinerators; Sodium; Solid wastes; Waste incineration; dioxin; ferrous ion; furan; hypochlorite; metal; organochlorine pesticide; pentachlorophenate sodium; polychlorinated dibenzodioxin; polychlorinated dibenzofuran; emission; emission control; emission inventory; organic pollutant; PCDD; PCDF; pollutant source; article; bleaching; China; field emission; hazardous waste; recycling; solid waste management; waste disposal; waste water management; Air Pollution; Benzofurans; China; Electronics; Incineration; Industry; Tetrachlorodibenzodioxin; Asia; China; Eurasia; Far East

Authors: Zhu J.-H., Young B.
Title: Numerical investigation and design of aluminum alloy circular hollow section columns
Affiliations: School of Civil Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, 518060, China; Department of Civil Engineering, The University of Hong Kong, Pokfulam Road, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Zhu, J.-H., School of Civil Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, 518060, China; Young, B., Department of Civil Engineering, The University of Hong Kong, Pokfulam Road, Hong Kong
Abstract: This paper presents a numerical investigation of aluminum alloy circular hollow section non-welded and welded columns using finite element analysis. A non-linear finite element model was developed and verified against fixed-ended column tests. The column specimens were extruded from heat-treated aluminum alloys of 6063-T5 and 6061-T6, and the ends of the columns were transversely welded to aluminum end plates for the welded columns. The non-welded columns without welding of end plates were also investigated. The welded columns were modeled by dividing the column into different portions along the column length, so that the heat-affected zone softening at both ends of the welded columns was included in the simulation. The initial local geometric imperfections of the columns were measured in this study. Geometric and material non-linearities were incorporated in the finite element model. The verified finite element model was used for a parametric study of fixed-ended aluminum alloy circular hollow section columns. A comparison of the column strengths predicted by the finite element analysis and the design strengths calculated using the current American, Australian/New Zealand and European specifications for aluminum structures was presented. The column strengths were also compared with the design strengths predicted by the direct strength method, which was developed for cold-formed carbon steel members. Design rules were proposed for aluminum alloy circular hollow section columns with transverse welds at the ends of the columns. Reliability analysis was performed to evaluate the reliability of the design rules. © 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Aluminum alloys; Buckling; Circular hollow section; Column; Design; Finite element analysis; Heat-affected zone; Parametric study; Transverse welds
Index Keywords: Alloys; Alumina; Aluminum; Aluminum alloys; Aluminum metallurgy; Beams and girders; Carbon steel; Design; Forecasting; Joints (structural components); Light metals; Metallic compounds; Modal analysis; Plates (structural components); Reliability; Reliability analysis; Steel; Steel structures; Welding; Buckling; Circular hollow section; Column; Finite element analysis; Heat-affected zone; Parametric study; Transverse welds; Columns (structural)

Authors: Zhu L.
Title: Chinese Practice in Public International Law: 2007 (II)
Affiliations: Faculty of International Law, China University of Political Science and Law (CUPL), Beijing, China; Peking University, China; Lund University, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Zhu, L., Faculty of International Law, China University of Political Science and Law (CUPL), Beijing, China, Peking University, China, Lund University, Sweden
Abstract: This part of the Survey covers materials reflecting Chinese practice in 2007 relating to VII. International Human Rights Law (Rule of Law at the National Level; Right of Self-Determination of Peoples; Racial Discrimination; Death Penalty; Re-education through Labour; Economic, Social and Cultural Rights; Women's Rights; Rights of the Child; Rights of the Older Persons; Dialogue on Human Rights; Human Rights Council; Implementation of Human Rights Instruments); VIII. International Humanitarian Law (Protection of Civilians in Armed Conflicts; Child and Armed Conflicts; Biological Weapons; Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons; Landmines; Explosive Remnants of War; Cluster Munitions; Right of Individual Claims for Violations of International Humanitarian Law; Establishment of National Committee on International Humanitarian Law); IX. International Law of Treaties (Reservations to Treaties; Effects of Armed Conflicts on Treaties); X. International Environmental Law (Principle of "Common but Differentiated Responsibilities"; Shared Natural Resources; Climate Change; Disaster Reduction); XI. Law on Diplomatic Relations; XII. International Criminal Law (International Criminal Court; ICTY and ICTR; Special Court for Serra Leone (SCSL); Special Tribunal for Lebanon; International Military Tribunal for Far East; Aut Dedere Aut Judicare; Immunity of State Officials from Foreign Criminal Jurisdiction; Criminal Accountability of United Nations Officials and Experts on Mission; Repatriation of Some Chinese in Guantanamo; Criminal Jurisdiction in Joint Military Exercises); XIII. Law on the United Nations (Sanctions by the United Nations; Amendment of the Charter of the UN; Security Council Reform); XIV. International Organizations Law; XV. International Law on State Responsibility (Responsibility of States for Internationally Wrongful Acts; Prevention of Transboundary Harm from Hazardous Activities and Allocation of Loss in the Case of Such Harm).

Authors: Zimmerman J.R., Bricker J.D., Jones C., Dacunto P.J., Street R.L., Luthy R.G.
Title: The stability of marine sediments at a tidal basin in San Francisco Bay amended with activated carbon for sequestration of organic contaminants
Affiliations: ENVIRON International Corporation, 4350 N. Fairfax Dr., Suite 300, Arlington, VA 22203, United States; Department of Geography and Environmental Engineering, 745 Brewerton Rd. Washington Hall, Room 5322, West Point, NY 10996, United States; URS Corporation, 1333 Broadway, Oakland, CA 94612, United States; Sea Engineering, Inc., 200 Washington St., Suite 210, Santa Cruz, CA 95060, United States; Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305 4020, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zimmerman, J.R., ENVIRON International Corporation, 4350 N. Fairfax Dr., Suite 300, Arlington, VA 22203, United States; Bricker, J.D., URS Corporation, 1333 Broadway, Oakland, CA 94612, United States; Jones, C., Sea Engineering, Inc., 200 Washington St., Suite 210, Santa Cruz, CA 95060, United States; Dacunto, P.J., Department of Geography and Environmental Engineering, 745 Brewerton Rd. Washington Hall, Room 5322, West Point, NY 10996, United States; Street, R.L., Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305 4020, United States; Luthy, R.G., Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305 4020, United States
Abstract: Recent laboratory studies show that adding activated carbon to marine sediments reduces the bioavailability of persistent organic contaminants, such as polychlorinated biphenyls, to benthic organisms. The present work investigates how mixing activated carbon into cohesive sediment affects the stability of sediment obtained from the intertidal zone at the Hunters Point Naval Shipyard Superfund site in South Basin, San Francisco Bay, CA. Our results show for these sediments that mixing activated carbon into sediment does not significantly affect stability of surface sediments, as measured by sediment erosion rate and critical shear stress for incipient motion, thus supporting the potential field application of this technique for in situ stabilization of persistent organic contaminants. Hydrodynamic modeling was used to estimate the maximum bottom shear stress encountered during high-wind storm events at the estuarine inlet from which the sediments were obtained. Comparison of estimated bottom shear stresses with measured critical shear stresses shows that surface sediments will not erode under normal, non-storm conditions. Bottom shear stresses caused by large waves under infrequent high-wind storm conditions may erode surface sediments for short periods of time. We conclude from sediment stability tests and hydrodynamic modeling that mixing activated carbon amendment with cohesive sediment at selected locations within South Basin will not reduce surface sediment stability nor result in significant erosion of treated sediments. © 2008 Elsevier Ltd.
Author Keywords: Carbon amendment; Sedflume; Sediment stability
Index Keywords: Activated carbon; Biochemistry; Erosion; Hydrodynamics; Marine pollution; Mixing; Shear flow; Ships; Stabilization; Storms; Submarine geology; Surficial sediments; Bottom shear stress; Carbon amendment; Critical shear stress; Organic contaminant; Persistent organic contaminants; Sedflume; Sediment stability; Stability of surfaces; Shear stress; activated carbon; organic compound; activated carbon; benthos; bioavailability; erosion; marine sediment; organic pollutant; sequestration (chemistry); shear stress; article; disaster; erosion; estuary; hydrodynamics; model; molecular stability; organic pollution; priority journal; sea pollution; sediment; shear stress; soil amendment; surface property; wind; California; North America; San Francisco Bay; United States

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Outer continental shelf air regulations consistency update for Florida
Abstract: EPA is finalizing the update of the Outer Continental Shelf (OCS) Air Regulations proposed in the Federal Register on 9/4/2008. Requirements applying to OCS sources located within 25 mi of states' seaward boundaries must be updated periodically to remain consistent with the requirements of the corresponding onshore area (COA), as mandated by section 328(a)(1) of the Clean Air Act. The portion of the OCS air regulations that is being updated pertains to the requirements for OCS sources for which the State of Florida has been designated COA. The effect of approving the OCS requirements for the State of Florida is to regulate emissions from OCS sources in accordance with the requirements onshore. These rules include revisions to existing rules that already apply to OCS sources. No comments were received on the 9/4/2008, proposal. This rule is effective on 1/21/2009. The incorporation by reference of certain publications listed in this rule is approved by the Director of the Federal Register as of 1/21/2009. List of subjects in 40 CFR part 55 include environmental protection, administrative practice and procedure, air pollution control, Continental Shelf, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, nitrogen dioxide, ozone, particulate matter, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and sulfur oxide.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California state implementation plan, Great Basin unified air pollution control district and Kern County air pollution control district
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the Great Basin Unified Air Pollution Control District (GBUAPCD) and Kern County Air Pollution Control District portions of the California SIP. Under authority of the CAAA, EPA is approving local rules that address permitting. One of the purposes of revisions of GBUAPCD Rule 201 relative to the SIP rule is that the exemption from permitting for internal combustion engines is modified to no longer exempt diesel engines larger than 50 brake hp that are also subject to the State air toxic control measure. This rule is effective on 2/3/2009 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 1/5/2009.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Energy policy: EU: Commission unveils its latest energy vision
Abstract: The European Commission, the EU's civil service, released its most recent advice on how to solve the energy problems that continue to vex the continent's planners - security of supply and climate change. The Commission calls for the development of a Baltic power interconnection plan to better link the region with the rest of the EU. It wants to see a "Southern Gas Corridor" developed to import gas from the Caspian and Middle East. It wants LNG imports to play a bigger role in the energy mix. The continent should also improve links to North Africa to tap that region's solar and wind power potential. It should also improve electricity interconnections throughout the continent. It also plans to develop a "blueprint" for a North Sea grid to connect planned offshore wind projects. Each of those proposals sounds good on paper, although the Commission's "agnosticism" about nuclear energy is on display again, with the decision left up to member states. The emphasis on renewable energy, which the review describes as the EU's "greatest potential source of indigenous energy", should help the continent meet its 20-20-20 targets (reduce greenhouse-gas emissions, increase the share of renewables in the energy mix, and cut energy waste - all by 20% and all by 2020). However, as energy prices continue to fall and governments in the EU run into recession, even these proposals could face difficulty.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Analysis: Aviation permits in EU ETS from 2012
Abstract: The European Council has formally adopted a directive to incorporate the aviation industry into the EU Emission Trading Scheme (EU ETS) from 2012. Carriers taking off or landing at European airports from 1/1/2012 will purchase permits to cover their emissions regardless of their nationality. The move is seen as the first step in reducing emissions from the global aviation sector. In 2012, the aviation scheme aims to cap emissions at 97% of the sector?s output between 2006-2008. In 2013 this cap will lower to 95%, with 85% of permits issued free of charge and l5% auctioned off. Meanwhile, GE Aviation and Rolls Royce are developing open rotor technology for the engines of the aircraft being developed by Airbus and Boeing to replace their A320 and 747, respectively. Wind tunnel trials are announced and GE predicts it will increase fuel efficiency and reduce emissions on commercial flights by 18% by 2018. Virgin Atlantic, Airbus and Air New Zealand are all investigating aircraft biofuels, while BASF plans to trial a high- temperature polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell in an Airbus A320.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Energy: Scenarios: Scramble or blueprints - We have a choice
Abstract: Ed Milliband, the UK Secretary of State for Energy and Climate Change, emphasized that the tough economic conditions were not an excuse to row back on the commitment to tackle global warming. This imperative to focus on the environmental challenge was central to the Stern Review, which emphasized that action is needed now to avoid the worst impacts of climate change. A discussion covers the potential consequences of being diverted form the climate challenges; need for governments, businesses, and individuals to work together to respond to the challenge; concerns on CO2 capture and storage; two possible futures; use of hydrogen as automotive fuel; truths identified by the Shell Energy Scenarios; and providing outcomes that are a better balance between economy, energy, and environment.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California State Implementation Plan, Ventura County Air Pollution Control District
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve revisions to the Ventura County Air Pollution Control District (VCAPCD) portion of the California SIP. These revisions concern the permitting of new or modified sources. The agency is proposing to approve local rules to regulate these procedures under the CAAA. The purposes of revisions relative to the SIP rule are as follows: VCAPCD Rule 26.3: The exemption from offset requirements for gasoline dispensing facilities that dispense into motor vehicles or marine pleasure craft, is removed. VCAPCD Rule 26.4.B.5: The banking of Emission Reduction Credits (ERC) for gasoline dispensing facilities that dispense into motor vehicles or marine pleasure craft, shall be allowed for no more than the amount of ERC provided by the applicant after 10/22/91. EPA is taking comments on this proposal and plan to follow with a final action. Any comments must arrive by 12/19/2008. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, intergovernmental relations, reporting and recordkeeping requirements.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Designation of areas for air quality planning purposes; State of California; PM-10; Revision of designation; Redesignation of the San Joaquin Valley Air Basin PM-10 nonattainment area to attainment; Approval of PM-10 maintenance plan for the San Joaquin Valley Air Basin; Approval of commitments for the East Kern PM-10 nonattainment area
Abstract: EPA is approving the State of California's request under the Clean Air Act (CAA or the Act) to revise the designation for the San Joaquin Valley (SJV) serious nonattainment area for particulate matter of ten microns or less (PM-10) (SJV nonattainment area) by splitting the area into two separate nonattainment areas: The San Joaquin Valley Air Basin (SJVAB) serious PM-10 nonattainment area and the East Kern serious PM-10 nonattainment area. The agency is also redesignating the SJVAB nonattainment area to attainment for the PM-10 NAAQS and approving the PM-10 maintenance plan, motor vehicle emissions budgets and conformity trading mechanism for the area. EPA is also excluding from use in determining that the area has attained the standard exceedances on 7/4/2007, and 1/4/2008, that EPA has concluded were caused by exceptional events. EPA is approving enforceable commitments by the Kern County Air Pollution Control District and the CARB to install a PM-10 monitor in the East Kern nonattainment area and to address CAA requirements under section 189(d) as necessary for the area. This rule is effective on 12/12/2008. The motor vehicle emission budgets are applicable as of 11/12/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Texas; Texas low-emission diesel fuel program
Abstract: EPA is approving three revisions to SIP for the state of Texas, which make changes to the Texas Low-Emission Diesel (TXLED) Fuel program. The changes will contribute to the reduction of NOx in the covered area. The revisions establish a replicable procedure for the State to approve Alternative Emission Reduction Plans, extend the date of state approvals, and bring marine diesel fuels under the TXLED program. The revisions also refine and clarify testing requirements. This final rule is effective on 11/24/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California State implementation plan, San Diego Air Pollution Control District, San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District, and Ventura County Air Pollution Control District
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the San Diego Air Pollution Control District, San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District, and Ventura County Air Pollution Control District portions of the California SIP. The revisions concern the permitting of air pollution sources. Section 110(a) of the CAA requires states to submit regulations that control VOC, NOx, particulate matter, and other air pollutants which harm human health and the environment. Permitting rules were developed as part of the local air district's programs to control these pollutants. This rule is effective on 12/23/2008 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 11/24/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Home office goes green
Abstract: Building Research Establishment's environmental assessment method (BREEAM) has conferred Home Office's new Sheffield headquarters with the city's first excellent award for building the UK's most environmental favorable building named as Vulcan House. The new building is fine-tuned by minimizing the ecological footprint, measuring CO 2 emissions through construction, operation, and eventually demolition. The building's excellent green credentials have led it to become a benchmark for future government construction projects. The group is attempting to centralize its operations in a brand new, purpose-built headquarters, and also to meet and actually go beyond the governments own environmental targets of becoming carbon neutral country by 2012. The building consists a steel frame built on CFA piles with composite floors composed of 150mm concrete over metal decking, and a natural green sedum roof of the building keeps the heat in and also minimizes the rain-run off.
Index Keywords: Building research establishments; Carbon neutrals; Composite floors; Construction projects; Ecological footprints; Environmental assessments; Environmental targets; Home offices; Sheffield; Steel frames; Construction industry; Environmental impact; Telecommuting; Buildings

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Energy efficiency rises up the political agenda
Abstract: European petrochemical firms are committing to programs that aim to cut costs by improving energy efficiency. An EU emission-trading scheme (ETS) that is unilateral, and not applied in other regions, is a threat to the European industry's international competitiveness. Cefic has initiated a campaign, dubbed the 'Tour d'Europe,' that stresses to legislators that the chemical industry needs a positive environment for innovation that can lead to development of sustainable technologies that improve energy efficiency. Business and industry consultants are also backing energy efficiency as the system of choice for reducing GHG emissions. Total, in addition to its efforts to improve energy efficiency at its industrial facilities, has initiated programs to assist its customers in reducing their emissions by offering them energy-saving products and the appropriate services to go with them. BASF has also adopted an extensive and varied approach to GHG emission reduction.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Environment, health and safety: Shattering the 'myth' of dirty oil
Abstract: The issue of dirty oil in Alberta is a myth, according to Alberta Premier Ed Stelmach. Alberta, Canada, has earmarked a $4-billion investment in controlling climate change, but government and industry efforts to date have effectively reduced oil sands exploration-related emissions by 45%/bbl produced since 1990. Alberta remain the only jurisdiction in North America and much of the world to enact a formal carbon capture and storage (CCS) program for harnessing and permanently storing greenhouse gas emissions of CO2. In July 2008, the governement, through its sanctioned Alberta Carbon Capture and Storage Development Council, contributed $2 billion to new CCS projects as part of the province's sweeping 2008 Climate Change Strategy. One element of the comprehensive environmental strategy directly impacing oil sands production is the government-enacted water conservation strategy. In March 2003, Alberta formally adopted a far-reaching water strategy with the release of "Water for life: Alberta's strategy for Sustainability". To reduce water usage, the multi-faceted strategy mandates that all existing or approved oil sands projects may withdraw 7lt; 3% over the average annual flow of the Athabasca River.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Government & policy concentrates: EPA tightens standards for lead emissions
Abstract: For the first time in three decades, EPA revised the nation's air-quality standards for lead, tightening the allowable lead level 10-fold to 0.15 μg of lead/cu m of air. With these stronger standards, a new generation of Americans is being protected from harmful lead emissions, especially children. Studies have linked exposure to low levels of lead with damage to children's development, including IQ loss. EPA will designate areas of the country that must take additional steps to reduce air emissions of lead by October 2011, and states will then have 5 yr to meet the new standards. Since 1980, lead emissions have decreased nearly 97% nationwide due in large part to the phaseout of leaded gasoline. An estimated 1300 ton/yr of lead is still emitted from various sources, e.g., general aviation gasoline.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans: Alabama: Approval of revisions to the visible emissions rule
Abstract: EPA is taking final action to approve revisions to the Visible Emissions portion of the SIP submitted to EPA by the State of Alabama, via the Alabama Department of Environmental Management, on 9/11/2003, and amended by a revision submitted to EPA on 8/22/2008. These revisions amend the requirements for units that are required to operate continuous opacity monitoring systems and that are not subject to any opacity limits other than those of the Alabama SIP. This rule will be effective 11/14/2008. The subjects listed in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, CO, lead, NO2, O3, particulate matter, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, SOx, and VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Cefic general assembly: Jourquin elected president; to build on progress made under predecessor
Abstract: Christian Jourquin, CEO of Solvay, elected as Cefic president during Cefic's General Assembly in Athens on October 4, 2008, for a two-year term, highlighted a need for the European chemical industry to respond to the challenges and opportunities created by climate change and scarce raw materials. Cornelis, in his address to the assembly, emphasized that the European chemical industry continues to show a remarkable capacity to adapt to the challenges of the global economy. The president also emphasized that the Reach program has proved to be a milestone of Cefic, while the chemical industry has played an important role for the reduction of CO2 emissions. Christian highlighted that the chemical industry opposes EU proposals to auction greenhouse gas emissions permits under the next phase of the region's Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS), beginning in 2013.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Boilers: NOx emissions, boilers and the LNG re-gasification ship
Abstract: The emissions from the ship's steam boilers have come under new scrutiny with the advent of LNG carriers having onboard regasification facilities, either as floating storage and regasification units (FSRU) or regasification vessels (RV). To date, the dual-fuel steam propulsion plants of conventional LNG carriers have no exhaust emission limits imposed on them, such as NOx and CO, unlike the heavy fuel burning engines of other ships, which must comply with IMO MARPOL Annex VI. However, with some ships now regasifying the LNG, the local land environmental regulations for air borne emissions are being imposed. With planning and evaluation, the shipowner can achieve the required NOx emission levels from the boiler plant for his FSRU or SRV/RV. The final configuration needs to be thoroughly assessed and optimized on a case-by-base basis.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: General interest - Quick takes: EPA waives Texas-specific diesel requirement
Abstract: The EPA temporarily waived certain diesel fuel requirements that apply only in the state of Texas following fuel supply disruptions caused by Hurricanes Gustav and Ike. Responding to a state request, EPA will allow the suspension of the Texas Low Emission Diesel (TxLED) requirements until 9/30/2008, but federal regulations for ultralow-sulfur diesel fuel with maximum sulfur content of 15 ppm still must be met. According to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality, the goal of the TxLED rule is to lower emissions of NOx and other pollutants from diesel motor vehicles and nonroad equipment. TxLED is part of the Texas federally approved SIP that was implemented in 2005.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Texas; Control of air pollution by permits for new construction or modification
Abstract: EPA is approving a revision to the Texas SIP, submitted by the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) on 10/9/2006. This SIP revision would require decreased newspaper notice for proposed air quality Standard Permits with statewide applicability to the following metropolitan areas: Austin, Dallas, Houston, and any other regional newspapers the TCEQ Executive Director designates on a case-by-case basis. EPA is approving this revision pursuant to section 110 of the Federal Clean Air Act. The list of Subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 includes air pollution control, CO, Pb, NO2, ozone, particulate matter, SOx, and VOC. This rule takes effect on 10/17/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Global monitor (Septemer 2008): U.S. small wind turbine market moving slowly
Abstract: The US market for wind turbines with rated capacities of < 1 kw and up to 100 kw grew 14% in 2007. With 9.7 Mw deployed, that brought the total small wind generating capacity in the country to 55 to 60 Mw. However, this growth paled in comparison with the solar photovoltaic industry, which spurted 53%, according to the American Wind Energy Association (AWEA) in its annual small wind turbine market report in July 2008. The discrepancy was in large part due to a federal tax incentive adopted for the solar industry in 2005, which the small wind industry does not have. AWEA reported that at least 58 US companies and 84 non-US companies manufacture or plan to manufacture small wind systems. Advances included sound-dampening devices, operation capability at lower wind speeds, and advanced blade design and manufacturing methods. Corroborating AWEA's findings, Carbon Trust, a UK government-funded independent company, released a study in August of small-scale wind energy's potential and found that this source could provide up to 0.4% of the UK's total electricity supply if 10% of households installed turbines at costs competitive with grid electricity. However, the study also found that small turbines in the UK would produce four times more energy and be considered cost-effective if installed in high-wind rural areas rather than in urban settings.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Global monitor (Septemer 2008): North Americans plan liquid makeover for coal
Abstract: Governor Joe Manchin of West Virginia would push renewable energy projects for his state. Manchin wants greater credibility for the state's manufacture of gasoline and other products from coal. Clean coal was a priority for West Virginia, pointing to approval by the state's Public Service Commission of a $2.3 billion clean coal plant proposed by American Electric Power in March 2008. An $800 million project by Consol Energy and Synthesis Energy System that will build the nation's first modern coal-to-liquids plant in West Virginia's northern panhandle is presented. Consol, the nation's largest producer of bituminous coal, and SES, a gasification company, have formed a new firm, Northern Appalachia Fuel, to proceed with the venture and proposed the plant be sited near Benwood, in Marshal County. Using SES's technology, coal would be converted to synthetic gas, which would then be used to produce about 720,000 ton/yr of methanol for the chemical industry. NAF is looking to convert some methanol into about 100 million gal/yr of 87 octane gasoline, and is currently negotiating for a license for ExxonMobil's methanol-to-gasoline technology. The project's plans include a carbon management strategy - specifically, plans to sequester CO2 in a deep saline aquifer - but NAF has yet to file for environmental and other permits to build the plant.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans and operating permits program; State of Missouri
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve a revision to the Missouri SIP and Operating Permits Program. EPA is approving a revision to the Missouri rule entitled "Submission of emission data, emission fees, and process information." These revisions will establish emission fees for the Missouri facilities as required yearly, align state rule reporting requirements with the Federal Consolidated Emission Reporting Rule, and decrease the required Emissions Inventory Questionnaire reporting frequency for affected installations. This direct final rule will be effective on 11/14/2008, without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comment by 10/15/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans North Carolina: Prevention of significant deterioration and nonattainment new source review rules
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve revisions to the North Carolina SIP submitted by the State of North Carolina in three submittals dated 11/30/2005, 3/16/2007, and 6/20/2008. The proposed revisions modify North Carolina's Prevention of Significant Deterioration and Nonattainment New Source Review permitting regulations in the SIP to address changes to the federal New Source Review (NSR) regulations, which were promulgated by EPA on 12/31/2002, and reconsidered with minor changes on 11/7/2003. In addition, the proposed revisions address an update to the NSR regulations promulgated by EPA on 11/29/2005 relating to the implementation of the 1997 8-hr ozone NAAQS. The proposed revisions include provisions for baseline emissions calculations, an actual-to-projected-actual methodology for calculating emissions changes, options for plant-wide applicability limits, recordkeeping and reporting requirements, and provisions recognizing NOx as a precursor to ozone. The 6/20/2008 SIP submittal also contains proposed revisions that are not related to EPA's 2002 NSR Reform Rules. EPA will propose action on those revisions in a separate Federal Register notice. Comments must be received on or before 10/9/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Ethanol manufacture through one-step cellulose liquefaction developed by Zhongren Bioenergy Company
Source title: China Petroleum Processing and Petrochemical Technology
Abstract: The pilot scale tests of one-step direct liquefaction of cellulose biomass developed by Huaibei Zhongren Bioenergy Technical Development Co Ltd in Anhui province was successfully carried out. This method is aimed to produce fuel and chemical feedstocks from cellulose biomass requiring mild reaction conditions, and all organic substances contained in the cellulose biomass can be completely converted without losses (without carbonization and gasification). The one-step direct liquefaction of cellulose biomass to manufacture bio-ethanol is the direction for development of bio-energy. Compared to the second-generation technology for the manufacture of ethanol from cellulose, the new technology can reduce carbon loss without using the expensive hydrolase, resulting in significant economic benefits.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Particle emissions from modern vehicles
Abstract: Experiments were carried out to measure particle emissions using the new regulatory procedures. The experiments provide both particulate matter (PM) and particle number (PM) emissions results on modern diesel and gasoline direct injection (GDI) vehicles tested under the driving conditions of the New European Driving Cycle, as well as on various transient and steady-state driving cycles. Very low PM and PN emissions could be achieved by today's engine and after-treatment technologies operating on ultra-low sulfur fuels. Implementing these technologies is expected to bring continuing improvements in auto emissions as the vehicle fleet is modernized. Diesel particulate filters (DPF) are also effective in reducing the ultra-fine particles, lowering the PN emissions over the New European Driving Cycle by about two orders of magnitude-compared to a vehicle without a DPF. Additional improvements in the combustion and after-treatment systems are likely to further improve the emissions performance of these vehicles.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: World news: News digest: USA: Tightening regulations
Abstract: New York Attorney General Andrew Cuomo will sue the EPA for failure to regulate greenhouse gas emissions from oil refineries. Cuomo has been joined in the lawsuit by 12 states and Washington DC. If successful, the EPA will be found in violation of the Clean Air Act and forced to require any new or renovated refineries to install technologies to reduce emissions. Industry has criticized such increases in regulations for hampering efforts at growth and expansion. However only three of the states involved (Delaware, New Mexico, and California) actually have any oil refineries.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: Industry: Green Streets challenge cutting CO2
Abstract: According to Centrica, British Gas' parent company, families have cut CO2 emissions by 20% and energy use by up to 30% in British Gas' "Green Streets" challenge over just 5 mo. A total of 64 families took part in the initiative aimed to show how consumers can help the UK government reach its target of reducing CO2 emissions by 20% in 1990 levels by 2010. The street, which reduces its energy usage and CO2 emissions the most over a year will win £50,000 to spend on making a community building more energy efficient. Starting from 1/28/2008, they have achieved the energy savings and CO2 reductions based on a mix of using energy efficient equipment (e.g., solar panels) and simple behavioral changes.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Emissions trading in the plantation, pulp and paper sectors: The New Zealand and Australian views
Abstract: The views of some of the leading industry people on the recently announced implementation of emissions trading schemes in the plantation, pulp and paper sectors in New Zealand and Australia are presented. Peter Allan, a manager, technical and environment, at Pan Pac Forest Products, New Zealand, said that the introduction of emissions trading will constitute the most significant economic and structural reform undertaken in Australia since the trade liberalization of the 1980. The New Zealand scheme does provide an allocation of units for at-risk industries, but also schedules a phase-out of the allocation over time, regardless of what the situation with the competitors. Miles Prosser, manager, pulp and paper with A3P, the Australian Plantation Products and Paper Industry Council, said that the implementation date in 2010 and the proposed scope of the Australian scheme will make it a significant player in the short term in global carbon markets.
Index Keywords: Air quality; Commerce; Competition; Forestry; Paper coating; Pulp; Raw materials; New zealand; Pulp and paper; Paper and pulp industry; Air Quality; Coating; Commerce; Competition; Economic Analysis; Emission; Forestry; Paper Industry; Plantations; Pulp Industry; Pulps; Raw Materials

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Outer continental shelf air regulations consistency update for California
Abstract: EPA is proposing to update a portion of the Outer Continental Shelf (OCS) Air Regulations. Requirements applying to OCS sources located within 25 mi of States' seaward boundaries must be updated periodically to remain consistent with the requirements of the corresponding onshore area, as mandated by section 328(a)(1) of the CAAA. The portions of the OCS air regulations that are being updated pertain to the requirements for OCS sources by the Ventura County Air Pollution Control District (APCD). The intended effect of approving the OCS requirements for the Ventura County APCD is to regulate emissions from OCS sources in accordance with the requirements onshore. Any comments must arrive by 9/19/2008. List of Subjects in 40 CFR Part 55 include environmental protection, administrative practice and procedures, air pollution control, hydrocarbons, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, NO2, NOx, ozone, particulate matter, permits, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, sulfur oxides.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Tennessee; Approval of revisions to the Nashville/Davidson county portion
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve a revision to SIP submitted by the State of Tennessee on 10/19/2007. The revision pertains to the Metropolitan Public Health Department, Pollution Control Division's Regulation Number 8, "Inspection and Maintenance of Light-Duty Motor Vehicles". The revision is part of Nashville/Davidson County's strategy to meet the requirements of EPA's 1997 8-hour ozone standard. Regulation Number 8 is amended by reducing the vehicle emission inspection fee to $9.00 and updating the definitions section. This direct final rule is effective 10/17/2008 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comment by 9/17/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Texas; Revisions to Chapter 117 and emission inventories for the Dallas/Fort Worth 8-hour ozone nonattainment area
Abstract: The EPA is approving portions of revisions to the SIP submitted by the State of Texas on 5/13/2005, to meet the 5% Increment of Progress (IOP) requirement for the Dallas/Fort Worth (DFW) nonattainment area. The agency is not taking action on the 5% IOP plan in this rulemaking. EPA is approving the 2002 base year inventory for the DFW 8-hr ozone nonattainment area. EPA is also approving emissions reductions from energy efficiency measures implemented within the DFW 8-hr ozone nonattainment area, and revisions to 30 TAC, Chapter 117, Control of Air Pollution From Nitrogen Compounds, concerning stationary reciprocating internal combustion engines operating within the DFW 8-hr ozone nonattainment area. These actions result in emissions reductions in the DFW 8-hr ozone nonattainment area and are taken in accordance with section 110 and part D of the Clean Air Act and EPA's regulations. This final rule is effective on 9/15/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Global monitor: PG&E mounts tidal power project
Abstract: Pacific Gas and Electric Co (PG&E) and Golden Gate Energy Co have agreed to undertake a comprehensive study of harnessing San Francisco Bay tides to generate power. Specifically, PG&E is committing up to $1.5 million to fund research by "third-party experts". A 2006 EPRI study identified San Francisco Bay as one of the world's most promising sites for tidal power technology. Key drivers of the research program are California's aggressive renewable portfolio standard (RPS) program and the state government's push to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. PG&E is now adding more than 300 Mw/yr in renewable resources. In 2008, the PG&E has already signed contracts to buy 274 Mw of wind, solar, geothermal, and other qualified renewables under the state's RPS program. The initial phases of the tidal current study will begin this summer and take about a year to complete.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: The Americas: California unveils emissions plan
Abstract: Californian regulators have drawn up an emissions and energy efficiency plan, including a carbon trading scheme partnered with US states and Canadian provinces. Mirroring the EU's emission trading scheme, California will auction pollution permits to utilities and industry. Polluters would need a permit for every ton of greenhouse gas pollutant emitted each year. California aims to produce 33% of electricity from renewables by 2020 and may use legislation to make new buildings and new appliances more efficient. Car makers could be forced to reduce the amount of emissions from vehicles sold in the state. Current US goals mandate an average of 35.7 mi/gal by 2015; California wants to raise the bar to 42 mi/gal.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Massachusetts; Amendment to Massachusetts' state implementation plan for transit system improvements
Abstract: EPA is approving a SIP revision submitted by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, which changes completion dates of delayed transit projects, provides interim deadlines for projects, maintains requirements for interim emission reduction offsets in the event a project becomes delayed, modifies the project substitution process, revises the list of required transit projects, and expands public participation in and oversight of the projects. The intended effect of this action is to substitute specific transit projects and 1000 park and ride spaces to replace certain transit projects currently approved into the SIP, and approve modifications to the delay and substitution procedures for transit projects. This action is being taken under the Clean Air Act. This rule is effective on 7/31/2008. List of Subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, lead, nitrogen dioxide, ozone, particulate matter, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, sulfur oxides, and VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California State Implementation Plan
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve revisions to the South Coast Air Quality Management District portion of the California SIP. These revisions concern NOx emissions from gaseous- and liquid-fueled internal combustion engines. EPA is approving a local rule that regulates these emission sources under the CAA. The agency is taking comments on this proposal and plans to follow with a final action. Comments must be received by 8/29/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Proposed Rule to Implement the 1997 8-Hour Ozone National Ambient Air Quality Standard: Addressing a portion of the phase 2 ozone implementation rule concerning reasonable further progress emissions reductions credits outside ozone nonattachment areas
Abstract: EPA proposes to revise its Phase 2 implementation rule for the 8-hr ozone NAAQS to address the US Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit's vacatur and remand of this rule. The Phase 2 Rule to implement the 8-hr NAAQS set forth an interpretation that certain emission reductions from outside a nonattainment area could be credited toward the 8-hour ozone RFP requirement. The rule stated that credit could be taken for VOC and NOx emission reductions within 100 and 200 km, respectively, outside the nonattainment area. The US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit vacated and remanded that portion of the Phase 2 Rule. Comments must be received on or before 8/20/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Texas; control of air pollution from VOC
Abstract: EPA is approving a SIP revision submitted by the State of Texas, which extends requirements to reduce VOC emissions in the Dallas-Fort Worth (DFW) area. Specifically, this revision extends requirements for control of VOC emissions to the five counties that were added to the DFW nonattainment area under the 1997 8-hr ozone standard designation: Ellis, Johnson, Kaufman, Parker, and Rockwall. These new VOC control requirements will be consistent for all nine counties in the DFW ozone nonattainment area. This direct final rule will be effective 9/15/2008 without further notice, unless EPA receives relevant adverse comments by 8/18/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Chementator: A cost-effective deprotection catalyst
Abstract: BASF's new series of palladium on carbon powder supports (Pd-CP) catalysts, named Blocking Group Removal (BGR) catalysts, is based on the discovered effect that both the metal-reduction state and the carbon-support characteristics have on overall activity and catalyst performance lifetime. Based on the deprotection reaction of 4-benzyloxy phenol to hydroquinone, the researchers determined that unreduced Pd-CP exhibited faster hydrogenation than its reduced analog. Building on patented research from the Engelhard Corp, the team also determined specific total pore volumes, surface areas and micropore surface areas at which the carbon-powder supports would yield higher activity. A BGR-2 catalyst containing 3% Pd-CP shows an activity number (34) equivalent to an older Escat 167 loaded at 5% Pd-CP. In addition to reducing cost, the BGR catalysts also exhibit enhanced filtration, as well as the ability to remove blocking groups in chiral synthesis without disturbing the chiral center. While conventional deprotection catalysts allow the use of limited number of primarily alcohol-based solvents, BGR catalysts can accept several others due to their higher intrinsic activity, including toluene, ethyl acetate, n-methyl pyrrolidone, and tetrahydrofuran.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Texas; Attainment demonstration for the Dallas/Fort Worth 1997 8-hour ozone nonattainment area
Abstract: EPA is proposing to conditionally approve the 1997 8-hr ozone attainment demonstration SIP revision for the Dallas/Fort Worth moderate 8-hr ozone nonattainment area (DFW area) submitted by the State of Texas on 5/30/2007, and supplemented on 4/23/2008. EPA is also proposing to approve the associated attainment Motor Vehicle Emissions Budgets, the Reasonably Available Control Measures demonstration, and two local control measures relied upon in the attainment demonstration. The proposed approval of the attainment demonstration is conditioned on Texas adopting and submitting to EPA prior to March 2009, a complete SIP revision to limit the use of Discrete Emission Reduction Credits, beginning in March 2009. Final conditional approval of the DFW 1997 8-hr ozone attainment demonstration SIP is contingent upon Texas adopting and submitting to EPA an approvable SIP revision for the attainment demonstration SIP's failure-to-attain contingency measures plan that meets section 172(c)(9) of the Clean Air Act. The agency is also proposing to fully approve the DFW area SIP as meeting the RACT requirement for VOC. EPA is proposing these actions in accordance with section 110 and part D of the Act and EPA's regulations. Comments must be received on or before 8/13/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Outer Continental Shelf air regulations update to include New Jersey State requirements
Abstract: EPA is proposing to update a portion of the Outer Continental Shelf (OCS) Air Regulations. Requirements applying to OCS sources located within 25 mi of States' seaward boundaries must be promulgated into part 55 and updated periodically to remain consistent with the requirements of the corresponding onshore area, as mandated by section 328(a)(1) of the Clean Air Act. The portion of the OCS air regulations that is being updated pertains to the requirements for OCS sources in the State of New Jersey. The intended effect of approving the OCS requirements for the State of New Jersey is to regulate emissions from OCS sources in accordance with the requirements onshore. The requirements discussed are proposed to be incorporated by reference into the Code of Federal Regulations and are listed in the appendix to the OCS air regulations. Comments must be received on or before 8/6/2008. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 55 include environmental protection, administrative practice and procedures, air pollution control, hydrocarbons, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, NO2, NOx, outer continental shelf, ozone, particulate matter, permits, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and SOx.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California state implementation plan, South Coast Air quality management district
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the South Coast Air Quality Management District (SCAQMD) portion of the California SIP. These revisions concern NOx and SOx emissions from facilities emitting ≥ 4 ton/yr of NOx or SOx in the year 1990 or any subsequent year under the SCAQMD's Regional Clean Air Incentives Market program. EPPA is approving local rules that regulate these emission sources under the CAAA. This rule is effective on 9/2/2008 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 8/4/2008.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Alberta pledges $2 billion for CCS
Abstract: The Alberta government is investing $2 billion for 3-5 large-scale carbon capture and storage (CCS) projects that will store ≤ 5 million ton of CO2 by 2015. The province has issued a request for expressions of interest to start identifying those CCS proposals with the greatest potential of being built quickly and those that provide the best opportunities to significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: United Kingdom: Yorkshire fields could capture 6% of UK emissions
Abstract: According to Amec, the UK could reduce its CO2 emissions by over 6% by capturing and storing emissions from a handful of large industrial sites in the Yorkshire and Humber regions. Working on behalf of Yorkshire Forward, Amec has studied the infrastructure network needed to connect local industrial emitters to suitable CO2 storage sites in the North Sea. According to Amec's project director Alastair Rennie, this would cost around $3.95 billion, which would cover the infrastructure needed to compress and transport the gas, but not the cost of capturing the gas or the technology at the wellhead. The plan sees a number of companies developing the infrastructure in stages. The Yorkshire and Humber area is ideally suited as a first project of this kind, because it has both a relatively small number of large-scale CO2 emitters, including the Drax, Eggborough, and Ferrybridge, and a large number of mature gas fields nearby with a well-understood, stable geology, ideal for carbon storage. Many of these are expected to be depleted between 2012 and 2030. Amec's calculations assume that only 25% of the CO2 emitted in the area would ultimately be abated, that is the amount captured minus the emissions associated with the process of gas capture and transportation. Even so, the contribution would be very noticeable, amounting to around 35.6 million ton/yr by 2030, or 6.4% of the country's total CO2 emissions in 2005. At best, Rennie calculates that the Yorkshire and Humber region could abate 46.3 million ton/yr of carbon by 2040.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Energy security
Abstract: The US Department of Energy (DOE) is working with industry partners for clean, domestic, innovative wind energy technologies that can compete with conventional fuel sources. The Castle on the Hudson estate has included renewable energy sources to the facility with the help of Juice Energy, which depends on wind energy, to address the problems caused by rising energy costs. CSX transportation, Michigan, along with Southeast Michigan Council of Governments, has introduced two ultra-low emission GenSet locomotives, which are expected to reduce nitrogen oxide emissions by 80%, and has also invested $1 billion to improve fuel economy and reduce emissions. University of Oklahoma's study of 267 US firms, aimed at improving environmental risk management, has found that the financial market are investing in green technology due to a reduced likelihood of litigation, government penalties, and catastrophic accidents.
Index Keywords: Air pollution; Conservation; Energy conservation; Energy utilization; Engines; Environmental protection; Finance; Fuel economy; Insurance; Investments; Leakage (fluid); Nitric oxide; Nitrogen; Nitrogen oxides; Nonmetals; Occupational risks; Renewable energy resources; Risk analysis; Risk management; Technology; Billion (CO); Conventional fuels; CSX Transportation (CO); Emissions (asphalt); Energy costs; Energy security; Environmental risks; Financial markets; Green technologies; Industry partners; Low emissions; Michigan (CO); Nitrogen oxide emissions; Renewable energy sources (RES); University of Oklahoma (OU); US Department of Energy (USDOE); Wind energy; Wind power

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Cimarex Energy plans to construct...
Abstract: Cimarex Energy plans to construct the world's largest carbon-sequestration project, injecting 3 million ton/yr of CO2. The Riley Ridge plant, in Sublette County, WY, will also produce methane and helium.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: Asia: GDF SUEZ secures carbon trading contracts in China
Abstract: GDF SUEZ has secured two carbon trading deals relating to hydro projects in the country, which are expected to be operational by end of 2009. The contracts cover a total estimated volume of about 1.6 million Certified Emissions Reduction (CERs) during the 2009-2012 contractual period. The CERs will be generated through one 48 Mw hydro project in Northwest China and one 99 Mw hydro project in Southeast China. The entry into these Emission Right Purchase Agreements underlines GDF SUEZ's strategy of contributing to CO2 emission-reduction activities in developing countries through strategic partnerships with major local companies in the field of Clean Development Mechanism projects.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: Middle East: Bahrain: a local petrochemicals company, Gulf Petrochemical Industries...
Abstract: Gulf Petrochemical Industries (GPIC) is to co-operate with Technimont of Italy and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries to set up a CO2-recycling plant on the island. GPIC claims it would be the first petrochemicals company in the region to use environmentally friendly technology.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Williams plans to add about 350m cfe/d of processing capacity...
Abstract: Williams plans to add about 350 million cu ft eq/day of processing capacity and 30,000 bpd of NGLs production capacity at the Echo Springs gas-processing plant in Carbon County, WY. The project, which would almost double the plant's capacity, is expected to come on line during late 2010.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Rush for tight gas renews production growth
Abstract: US gas production is once again growing strongly. According to EIA, one field in the Barnett Shale now accounts for more than 6% of the gas produced in the lower 48 states. The EIA projects that US marketed-gas production growth in 2008 will be 7.8%, with a further increase of 3.8% for 2009. By contrast, consumption growth is projected at 2.7% in 2008 and 2.2% in 2009. Strong year-over-year production growth resulted from the development of onshore fields, particularly in Texas and Wyoming. As a result of the growth of US production, EIA projects that net gas imports from Canada will continue to fall until 2030 and it does not expect indigenous production to meet both this shortfall and projected growth in demand over that period. Thus, LNG imports are still expected to increase - from 0.5 tcf in 2006 to 2.8 tcf by 2030. The long-term outlook for LNG depends on a variety of unpredictable market forces, such as the resilience of US gas demand to high prices, the availability of LNG in what is expected to be a tight market, the incoming government's climate-change policy and whether unconventional gas supply grows as expected.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Tech notes: Gas analyzer technology boosts potential for converting biogas to electric power
Abstract: BioEnergy Solutions launched California's first biogas-to-pipeline injection project in Fresno County, central California. The project is using renewable natural gas derived from animal waste at a PG&E site. According to Roy Kuga, vice president of energy supply at PG&E, with nearly 2 million dairy cows in California, there is great potential for the state's agriculture and power sectors to work together to address the challenges of climate change. The project, located in the town of Riverdale in western Fresno County, will use manure from the Vintage Dairy's 5000 milk-producing cows and calves. The waste is flushed into a covered lagoon that traps the methane gas produced as the manure decomposes. The biogas is upgraded, or scrubbed to remove corrosive materials to meet PG&E's industry-leading environmental standards for power plants and then delivered to PG&E through the utility's pipeline. PG&E uses the natural gas to deliver renewable electricity to its customers in central and northern California. The methane production system also reduces emissions of methane, a greenhouse gas 21 times more potent than CO2, by 70%. SpectraSensors moisture analyzer offers assurance that the project will continually meet PG&E's high standards.
